questions.text: Optic nerve glioma is seen in:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NF-1 (Neurofibromatosis Type 1)

 

NF-1 is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas) and areas of abnormal skin coloration. Among other complications, individuals with NF-1 may develop optic nerve gliomas, which are benign brain tumors that involve the optic nerves. These tumors typically appear in childhood and can cause vision problems.

 

Also seen in NF-1 are Lisch Nodules

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B Tuberous Sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder that causes noncancerous tumors to form in many different organs, primarily in the brain, eyes, heart, kidney, skin, and lungs. While it is associated with a variety of brain tumors, optic nerve gliomas are not a characteristic feature of tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C Sturge-Weber syndrome: Sturge-Weber syndrome is a rare disorder present at birth, characterized by a port-wine stain birthmark on the face and neurological abnormalities. There is the development of abnormal blood vessels on the brain's surface, but optic nerve gliomas are not typically associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Option D Von Hippel-Lindau disease: Von Hippel-Lindau disease is a hereditary condition associated with tumors arising in multiple organs. Hemangioblastomas of the brain, spine, and retina, pheochromocytomas of the adrenal gland, and renal cell carcinomas are common. However, optic nerve gliomas are not commonly seen in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic nerve glioma, is a type of brain tumor that affects the optic nerve, is commonly associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1) and not typically seen in Tuberous Sclerosis, Sturge-Weber syndrome, or Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare, and corneal precipitates. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin analogs

 

  • The clinical vignette suggests anterior uveitis with a raised intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues like latanoprost increase uveoscleral outflow and lower intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues act by stimulating prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases that increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Prostaglandin analogues should be used with caution in patients with uveitis, iritis, cystoid macular edema, and herpes simplex keratitis.
  • Prostaglandin analogues are the least suited for use in this patient as they can worsen the anterior uveitis.
  • PG Analogues can also cause cystoids macular edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: These are generally safe in uveitis unless contraindicated for systemic reasons.

 

Option B. Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic can be used for quick reduction of IOP in acute settings but does not exacerbate uveitis.

 

Option C. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: Also safe for use in reducing IOP in uveitis, unless systemic contraindications exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with anterior uveitis and high IOP, prostaglandin analogs should be avoided due to their potential to worsen intraocular inflammation and the risk of inducing or exacerbating cystoid macular edema. Other options such as beta blockers, mannitol, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can be considered based on the individual patient's overall health and specific eye condition.

questions.text: Identify the refractive error: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myopia

 

As a result of parallel rays being focused in front of the retina in the image above, myopia is indicated as the refractive error.

 

Myopia, also referred to as "short sight," is a dioptric condition of the eye in which incident parallel rays focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina while accommodation is at rest.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presbyopia: It is an age-related condition characterized by a gradual loss of the eyes' ability to focus on nearby objects, due to the hardening of the lens inside the eye.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia: Also known as farsightedness, in this condition, light rays entering the eye focus behind the retina. Individuals with hypermetropia see distant objects more clearly than close ones.

 

 

 

Option D. Astigmatism: This refractive error occurs due to an irregular curvature of the cornea or lens, which causes light to be focused at multiple points in front of, on, or behind the retina, leading to blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myopia results from the focusing of light in front of the retina, making distant objects appear blurry, a condition often corrected with concave lenses.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who had undergone an uneventful cataract surgery with intraocular lens implantation, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance in the operated eye, 36 hours post operatively. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Intravitreal antibiotics

 

The given image shows an inflamed eye with the presence hypopyon, which along with the history of a recent cataract surgery is suggestive of endophthalmitis.

 

Endophthalmitis is an inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball associated with exudate pouring in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

 

Modes of infection:

 

  1. Exogenous: following perforating injuries, perforation of infected corneal ulcers, or postoperative infections.
  2. Endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis: occurs rarely through the bloodstream from some infected focus.
  3. Secondary infections from surrounding structures: rare.
  • Bacterial endophthalmitis: most frequent pathogens are gram-positive cocci, such as staphylococcus epidermidis and staphylococcus aureus.
  • Fungal endophthalmitis: comparatively rare, caused by aspergillus, fusarium, candida, etc.
  • Cardinal features: Pain, lid swelling, and decreased vision. Inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and hypopyon may also occur.
  • Treatment:
    • Intraocular fluid from anterior chamber or vitreous biopsy is sent for gram staining, KOH mount and culture.
    • Intravitreal injection of antibiotics is the primary therapy. Patient needs to be monitored daily to assess for resolution of clinical symptoms and repeat intravitreal antibiotic injections may be given as required.
    • Topical broadspectrum antibiotics, cycloplegics are also given simultaneously.
    • Oral steroids may be given.
    • Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis..

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous steroids: Not the primary treatment for endophthalmitis. Steroids may be used to reduce inflammation but not as the main intervention.

 

Option B. Intravenous antibiotics: Systemic antibiotics have limited effectiveness due to poor penetration into the eye.

 

Option C. Bandage and padding of the eye: Provides no therapeutic benefit for endophthalmitis and delays appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravitreal antibiotics are the primary treatment for endophthalmitis, a severe postoperative complication characterized by inflammation and hypopyon. Early and aggressive treatment is crucial to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: Silent choroid on FFA is a feature of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stargardt's disease

 

Silent choroid / Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of Stargardt's disease.

 

 

The 'silent choroid' or 'dark choroid' phenomenon is caused by the obscuration of the background choroidal fluorescence due to diffuse abnormalities in the retinal epithelium (RE). The accumulation of lipofuscin within the RE is a hallmark feature of Stargardt disease / Fundus flavimaculatus (FFM), which is the most prevalent type of macular dystrophy.

 

Signs:

 

  • The macula may initially be normal, later progressing to an oval 'snail slime' or 'beaten bronze appearance and subsequently to geographic atrophy.
  • Numerous yellow-white round, oval or fish-shaped lesions are seen at the level of the RPE.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Visual fields show central loss
  • FFA - Dark choroid, the macula shows mixed hyper and hypofluorescence. Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA). shows hypofluorescent spots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Best's disease: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin-like material within the RPE but does not typically feature a silent choroid on FFA.

 

Option C. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD): AMD is associated with drusen and neovascular changes rather than a silent choroid.

 

Option D. Cystoid macular edema: This involves swelling of the macular region of the retina due to fluid accumulation in the cystoid spaces, not linked with the silent choroid phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The silent choroid or dark choroid on FFA is a distinctive feature of Stargardt's disease, caused by lipofuscin accumulation in the retinal pigment epithelium, which blocks the normal choroidal fluorescence. Recognizing this feature is crucial in diagnosing and differentiating Stargardt’s disease from other macular disorders.

questions.text: In extroversion, what is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus muscle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left medial rectus

 

The yoke muscle of the right LR is the left MR.

 

Yoke muscles are the primary muscles in each eye that accomplish a given version (eg, for right gaze, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus muscles).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is involved in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the left eye, not in coordinating rightward gaze with the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Left inferior rectus: This muscle is responsible for depression and adduction of the left eye, not relevant to the rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left superior rectus: This muscle is involved in elevation and intorsion of the left eye, not in the horizontal movement to the right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In extroversion (rightward gaze), the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus (which abducts the right eye) is the left medial rectus (which adducts the left eye), enabling coordinated horizontal movement.

choices.text: It is called Argyl Robertson pupil.
﻿﻿﻿The vision is normal in right eye.
﻿﻿﻿Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes.

 

The image suggests Marcus Gunn pupil, which is seen in optic neuritis. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal.

 

  • ﻿﻿The condition is named after the scientist, Robert Marcus Gunn who belongs to Scotland.

 

Presentation:

 

  • Pupil appears to dilate when light is shone on it (this is also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect or RAPD).
  • The affected pupil constricts less than the unaffected pupil when light is shone on it.
  • The affected pupil may even dilate when light is removed from it (this is known as the Marcus Gunn pupil phenomenon).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Diagnosed by a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) test, also called swinging flash light test, which involves comparing the pupillary response of the affected eye to that of the unaffected eye when a light is shone on them.
  • In the swinging flashlight test, a light is alternately shone into the left and right eyes. A normal response would be equal constriction of both pupils, regardless of which eye the light is directed at. This indicates an intact direct and consensual pupillary light reflex. When the test is performed in an eye with an afferent pupillary defect, light directed in the affected eye will cause only mild constriction of both pupils (due to decreased response to light from the afferent defect), while light in the unaffected eye will cause a normal constriction of both pupils (due to an intact efferent path, and an intact consensual pupillary reflex). Thus, light shone in the affected eye will produce less pupillary constriction than light shone in the unaffected eye.

 

Management:

 

  • Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause of the afferent pupillary defect, such as optic neuritis or a retinal detachment.
  • In cases where the underlying cause cannot be treated, the patient may need to wear an eye patch to alleviate symptoms caused by the unequal pupillary responses.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is called Argyl Robertson pupil: Incorrect, as Argyl Robertson pupils are associated with neurosyphilis and react to accommodation but not to light.

 

Option B. Both eyes are abnormal: Incorrect, the image specifically shows an abnormal reaction in one eye compared to a normal reaction in the other.

 

Option C. The vision is normal in the right eye: Incorrect as it is not specifically addressed in the image or scenario provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Marcus Gunn pupil, indicative of an RAPD, is a significant sign of optic nerve dysfunction often seen in conditions like optic neuritis. Detecting this early through the swinging flashlight test can guide further diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant presents with the following image showing cloudy cornea in one eye. On examination, there is conjunctival congestion and mucopurulent discharge. Mother gives history of difficult vaginal delivery. (Twisted PYQ)

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ophthalmia neonatorum

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of mucopurulent discharge along with conjunctival congestion in a neonate with history of vaginal delivery strongly suggests ophthalmia neonatorum. This condition typically presents with corneal haze, redness, and discharge within the first month of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital Glaucoma: While it presents with corneal haze, the primary symptoms are tearing and photophobia. Mucopurulent discharge is not a typical feature.

 

Option C. Peters Anomaly: This is a developmental anomaly with central corneal opacity present since birth, but doesn't present with mucopurulent discharge or conjunctival congestion.

 

Option D. Corneal Dystrophy: These are inherited conditions affecting corneal transparency but don't present with acute inflammation or discharge in early infancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early recognition of ophthalmia neonatorum is crucial as delayed treatment can lead to corneal scarring and permanent visual impairment. The presence of mucopurulent discharge in a neonate should raise high suspicion, particularly with history of vaginal delivery.

questions.text: During an ocular examination, the ophthalmologist observes the presence of the shifting fluid sign in the patient. This finding suggests that the patient might have which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exudative RD

 

  • Shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment.
  • In serous retinal detachment, there is subretinal accumulation of serous fluid mostly due to breakdown in blood-retinal barrier.
  • Fluid shifts to the dependent portion when head position is altered.
  • Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration and lacks a retinal tear or preretinal traction.
  • Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells, and retinal breaks.
  • Traction RD has a concave configuration, absent breaks, and severely reduced retinal mobility.
  • Shifting fluid is absent in traction RD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traction RD: Tractional retinal detachment is caused by fibrovascular proliferation and contraction of epiretinal membranes, leading to mechanical traction on the retina. It has a concave configuration and lacks shifting fluid due to the tethering of the retina by fibrous tissue. Retinal mobility is severely reduced, and retinal breaks are usually absent.

 

Option C. Rhegmatogenous RD: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs due to a retinal tear or hole that allows vitreous fluid to enter the subretinal space. It presents with signs such as tobacco dust (Shafer's sign) in the anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood, inflammatory cells, and visible retinal breaks. Shifting fluid is not a characteristic feature of rhegmatogenous RD.

 

Option D. Retinal Dialysis: Retinal dialysis is a type of retinal tear that typically occurs at the ora serrata, where the retina is particularly thin and prone to tearing. It is most often seen in younger patients or those who have experienced trauma. Shifting fluid is not a specific feature of retinal dialysis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient is prescribed a corrective lens with the following prescription: -1D spherical, -2D cylinder at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error is being corrected? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) With the rule astigmatism

 

  • In the context of refractive errors corrected by lenses, here's an explanation of each type of astigmatism as mentioned:

 

In this condition, the eye's steepest curve is oriented vertically (up and down). This is the most common type of astigmatism. The -2D cylindrical correction at 180 degrees indicates that the correction is applied horizontally, which compensates for the steeper vertical curvature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Against the Rule Astigmatism: Here, the steepest curvature is horizontal (side to side). Corrective lenses for this type would have cylindrical axes oriented vertically (usually at 90 degrees).

 

Option C. Simple Astigmatism: This occurs when one principal meridian is emmetropic (normal), meaning no refractive error, while the other has myopia (short-sightedness) or hyperopia (long-sightedness). There is only one refractive error to correct.

 

Option D. Mixed Astigmatism: This type features one meridian with myopia and the perpendicular meridian with hyperopia. Essentially, one axis is near sighted, and the other is farsighted, requiring complex lens corrections to address both issues simultaneously.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When prescribed corrective lenses for astigmatism, understanding the orientation and type of astigmatism (with the rule, against the rule, simple, or mixed) is crucial for ensuring the correct lens type and orientation is used, thus maximizing visual clarity and health.

questions.text: What is the adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atropine Sulfate eye ointment

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as the nonspecific supportive treatment in both bacterial as well as a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is utilized in the management of fungal corneal ulcers primarily to relieve symptoms like pain due to ciliary spasm and to prevent complications such as the formation of posterior synechiae. Atropine achieves this by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscles, thus providing a therapeutic benefit in the treatment of corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilocarpine e/d: Generally used to contract the pupil in glaucoma treatment, not appropriate for corneal ulcers as it can increase pain by causing ciliary spasm.

 

Option B. Lignocaine e/d: An anesthetic used for temporary pain relief but does not serve as adjuvant therapy in managing ulcers.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone e/d: A corticosteroid, generally avoided in fungal infections due to its potential to exacerbate infections by suppressing immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcers to relieve pain and prevent the formation of posterior synechiae by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscle.

questions.text: The following image indicates: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor palsy

 

The given image suggests oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

The central image shows the eyes in primary gaze where the patient's left eye has deviated down and out. There is also ptosis of the left eyelid. From the eye movements, it can be seen that adduction, elevation, and depression are absent in the left eye.

 

All of these findings indicate oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis: This is due to the weakness of the levator muscle.
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out"): This is due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest: This is due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction: This is due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation: This is due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression: This is due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation: This is due to parasympathetic palsy.
  • Normal abduction: This is due to the intact lateral rectus

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trochlear nerve palsy: Primarily affects the superior oblique muscle, leading to vertical diplopia and head tilt but does not cause ptosis or pupil involvement.

 

Option B. Lateral rectus palsy: Would lead to medial deviation of the eye due to unopposed action of the medial rectus muscle, affecting horizontal eye movement.

 

Option C. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia: Characterized by impairment of horizontal eye movements, particularly affecting the adduction of the eye on the side of the lesion, with nystagmus in the abducting eye, typically not involving the eyelid or pupil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor palsy involves multiple dysfunctions including ptosis, "down and out" eye position, and possibly a dilated pupil. Recognizing the full range of symptoms is critical for a correct diagnosis, indicating a comprehensive evaluation of cranial nerve III integrity.

questions.text: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye exam. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ptosis of right eye

 

The patient has ptosis of the right eye. Ptosis is abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid to a level that covers more than 2mm of the superior cornea. Ptosis is generally unilateral, in over 70% of individuals. The drooping in this case is significant enough to cover a portion of the pupil, thereby obstructing part of the visual field, which is characteristic of ptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entropion of right eye: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid margin, not observed in the provided image.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos of right eye: Refers to the inability to close the eyelids completely, not evident here.

 

Option D. Exophthalmos of left eye: Characterized by the protrusion of the eyeball, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis, particularly of the type seen in this patient, is typically caused by a dysfunction or disconnection of the levator muscle or its aponeurosis, either congenital or acquired.

 

Types:

 

 

Note: Pseudoptosis is apparent but not true drooping of the eyelid. Causes include lack of support of the lids by the globe (orbital volume deficit like an artificial eye, microphthalmos, or enophthalmos), contralateral lid retraction, ipsilateral hypotropia, brow ptosis, or dermatochalasis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old patient presents with gradual onset blurring of near vision over 6 months, despite having undergone cataract surgery with IOL implantation 2 years ago. Distance vision remains stable at 6/9. On examination, there is posterior capsular opacification and anterior displacement of the IOL. Which of the following refractive errors best explains the patient's symptoms? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positional Myopia

 

Explanation: 

 

The case presents positional myopia due to:

  • Anterior displacement of IOL causing a myopic shift
  • PCO development leading to visual symptoms
  • Post-cataract surgery status rules out index changes in natural lens
  • Timing and progression pattern matches mechanical displacement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axial Myopia: Present since childhood/young age, wouldn't develop post-cataract surgery

 

Option B. Curvatural Myopia: Related to corneal/lenticular curvature changes, unlikely with IOL

 

Option D. Index Myopia: Requires presence of natural lens, not applicable in pseudophakia

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-cataract surgery patients, refractive changes can occur due to IOL position changes. Understanding the relationship between IOL position and refractive error is crucial for managing post-operative complications. PCO and IOL displacement should be considered when evaluating vision changes in pseudophakic patients.

questions.text: Sudden loss of vision without fundal glow without history of trauma is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitreous hemorrhage

 

Vitreous hemorrhage is characterized by sudden loss of vision and absence of fundal glow without a history of trauma. This occurs because blood in the vitreous cavity blocks light from reaching the retina, preventing visualization of the fundus and causing vision loss. The sudden onset and lack of fundal glow are key diagnostic features of vitreous hemorrhage.

 

 

Causes of Vitreous hemorrhage:

 

  • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR)
  • Eales Disease
  • Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO)
  • Post trauma

 

Treatment:

 

  • Initial Step: Patients should maintain a propped-up position to help settle the blood within the eye.
  • Natural Resolution: Wait for the hemorrhage to clear up spontaneously, as many cases resolve without intervention.
  • Surgical Treatment: If the hemorrhage does not resolve naturally and vision remains impaired, a vitrectomy may be performed. This surgery involves removing the blood-filled vitreous and replacing it with a saline solution to restore the eye's shape and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute congestive glaucoma: While this can cause sudden vision loss, it typically doesn't result in complete loss of fundal glow. The fundus may appear hazy due to corneal edema, but it's usually still visible to some extent.

 

Option C. Optic atrophy: This condition leads to gradual vision loss rather than sudden loss. Moreover, the fundus and optic disc would still be visible during examination, allowing for clear visualization of the atrophied optic nerve.

 

Option D. Acute anterior uveitis: This primarily affects the front part of the eye and doesn't typically cause sudden, severe vision loss or loss of fundal glow unless there are extensive inflammatory membranes in the pupillary area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden loss of vision combined with absence of fundal glow, without a history of trauma, is highly characteristic of vitreous hemorrhage. This condition requires prompt evaluation to determine the underlying cause, which could include proliferative diabetic retinopathy, Eales disease, central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), or other vascular abnormalities of the retina

questions.text: According to World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) VA < 3/60

 

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction. This definition has been in place since 2017 and has also been adopted by India’s National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI). The definition includes three criteria, any of which can classify a person as blind:

 

  1. Visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with best correction possible
  2. Visual field less than 10 degrees
  3. Inability to count fingers at 3 meters

 

Note – VA < 6/60 was the old Indian criteria for blindness before 2017, where visual acuity less than 6/60 and visual field less than 20 degrees were considered blind. However, this is no longer the current WHO or Indian standard.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO definition of blindness, adopted since 2017, is visual acuity less than 3/60 in the better eye with best possible correction, or visual field less than 10 degrees, or inability to count fingers at 3 meters.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

The patient presenting with progressive visual loss in the right halves of both eyes is suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right visual cortex: Lesions in the right visual cortex would cause left homonymous hemianopia, not right. The visual cortex processes information from the contralateral visual field.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Lesions in the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes. This is due to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.

 

Option D. Right optic nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause vision loss in the right eye only, not in both eyes. It would not result in a homonymous visual field defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right homonymous hemianopia, characterized by loss of the right visual field in both eyes, is caused by a lesion in the left optic tract.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with steroids. She also has a history of transverse myelitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuromyelitis optica

 

The most probable diagnosis is neuromyelitis optica (NMO).

 

NMO is a demyelinating autoimmune disease that primarily affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. Patients with NMO can present with recurrent episodes of optic neuritis, which can result in decreased visual acuity, as well as myelitis, which can cause weakness, sensory loss, and bladder dysfunction.

 

The patient's history of recurrent episodes of diminution of vision that recovers on treatment with steroids is consistent with optic neuritis, which is a common presenting feature of NMO. The history of transverse myelitis also supports a diagnosis of NMO, as myelitis is a common feature of the disease.

 

Management of acute attacks:

 

  • High-dose glucocorticoids
  • Plasma exchange.

 

Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses:

 

  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Rituximab
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Azathioprine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hereditary spastic quadriplegia: This is a genetic disorder affecting motor functions and does not involve optic neuritis or transverse myelitis.

 

Option B. Subacute combined degeneration: Typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency affecting the spinal cord, but not specifically linked with optic neuritis.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis (MS): While MS can present with symptoms similar to NMO, including optic neuritis and spinal cord involvement, the pattern of attacks and the severity of symptoms in the context of transverse myelitis point more specifically to NMO, especially considering the distinct pathophysiology and antibody profiles (e.g., anti-aquaporin-4 antibodies).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuromyelitis optica should be considered in patients presenting with recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis, especially when there is a good response to steroid treatment. Distinguishing NMO from multiple sclerosis is crucial, as treatment and prognosis differ significantly between these conditions.

questions.text: What dye is used in staining the anterior capsule of the lens?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trypan blue

 

Trypan blue dye is commonly used to stain the anterior capsule of the lens during cataract surgery, specifically to facilitate the creation of a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis. This dye helps surgeons to visualize the capsule better, making the procedure safer and more precise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein green: This dye is used to stain corneal epithelial defects and is not used for staining the anterior lens capsule.

 

Option C. Brilliant blue: This dye is used in retinal surgeries to stain the internal limiting membrane (ILM), aiding in ILM peeling during macular hole surgeries. It is not used for lens capsule staining.

 

Option D. Rose Bengal: This dye stains dead or devitalized cells and is used in the diagnosis of conditions like dry eye syndrome. It is not used for staining the anterior capsule of the lens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trypan blue dye is used for staining the anterior capsule of the lens during cataract surgery to aid in the creation of a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis.

 

Various Dyes used in Opthalmology -

questions.text: In which type of cataract surgery is suturing with 10-0 nylon performed? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra capsular cataract surgery

 

Explanation:

 

In extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE), a larger incision (approximately 10 to 12 millimeters) is made at the limbus to remove the lens nucleus in one piece. Due to the size of this incision, suturing is necessary to close the wound properly. The suturing is typically performed using 10-0 nylon monofilament. This method can involve interrupted sutures or continuous suturing to ensure the wound is securely closed and to promote proper healing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phacoemulsification: This technique involves making a much smaller incision (around 3 millimeters or less) through which the lens is emulsified and aspirated. Suturing is generally not required because the small incision is self-sealing.

 

Option B. FLACS (Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery): This advanced technique uses a femtosecond laser to create precise incisions and to perform capsulotomy and lens fragmentation. Similar to phacoemulsification, the incisions made are small and typically do not require suturing.

 

Option C. Manual small incision cataract surgery (SICS): In SICS, the incision size is between 6 to 8 millimeters. Depending on the quality of the incision and tunnel, suturing may or may not be required. Good surgical technique can often avoid the need for suturing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra capsular cataract extraction (ECCE) requires suturing with 10-0 nylon due to the larger incision size necessary for removing the lens nucleus in one piece.

questions.text: All are ocular manifestations of dengue except: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cataract

 

  • Cataract is not a common ocular manifestation of dengue infection.
  • Dengue infection can have various manifestations in different organ systems, primarily characterized by inflammation and bleeding.
  • Until recently, eye involvement was not recognized as a common feature of dengue infection, apart from retro-orbital pain.
  • The potential pathogenic mechanisms for dengue-related eye involvement may include direct viral effects on the eye, immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Common in dengue due to increased fragility of blood vessels and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Uveitis: While less common, uveitis can occur in dengue fever as part of a systemic immune response to the infection.

 

Option D. Retinal hemorrhage: This is a direct consequence of the hemorrhagic tendency in dengue fever, related to thrombocytopenia and vascular fragility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular manifestations of dengue:

 

  • Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir.
  • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis.
  • Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankyloblepharon

 

Ankyloblepharon is a condition where the upper and lower eyelids become attached to each other. This can happen as a congenital anomaly or due to adhesions that form during the healing process of traumatic wounds, ulcers, or chemical burns affecting the eyelid margins. Treatment involves removing the adhesions between the eyelid margins. In cases where adhesions extend to the angles, epithelial grafts should be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva in which the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball.

 

The image given below shows symblepharon.

 

 

Option C: Congenital blepharophimosis is a condition in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It can be congenital or acquired and is due to a vertical skin fold at the lateral canthus. No treatment is required. In some cases, canthoplasty is done.

 

 

Option D: Congenital ptosis is a condition present since birth and is characterized by drooping of one or both upper eyelids due to developmental defects or weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. The affected individuals may also have lid lag on downward gaze. The most common treatment for congenital ptosis is surgical correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankyloblepharon involves the fusion of the eyelid margins, which can be congenital or acquired, and requires surgical intervention to correct the adhesion and restore normal eyelid function and appearance.

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

1-b: Colour vision - Ishihara chart:

 

Colour vision is tested with Ishihara plates, which is a pseudoisochromatic chart. There are patterns of coloured and grey dots that reveal one pattern to persons with normal colour vision and another to those with the colour deficiency.

 

The below image shows a representative plate of the Ishihara chart.

 

 

Limitation of ischihara chart: Ischihara chart is useful as a screening tool for colour blindness. It mainly tests for red-green blindness.

 

In order to check blue-yellow blindness other tests such as 100 Hue Test are required.

 

2-a: Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer:

 

An applanation tonometer is used to measure the intraocular pressure. It is based on the Imbert-Fick law, which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

 

P = W/A

 

The following is an image of the applanation tonometer:

 

 

There are two types of applanation tonometers:

 

(1) In which the surface area of the prism is constant – Eg

 

  1. Goldmann Applanation Tonometer (GAT):
    • The Goldmann tonometer is one of the most widely used and considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It consists of a prism that is gently applied to the anesthetized cornea, flattening a small area.
    • The amount of force required to flatten the cornea is directly related to intraocular pressure.
  2. Perkins Applanation Tonometer:
    • The Perkins tonometer is a handheld, portable device used for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It is similar in principle to the Goldmann tonometer but is more compact and easier to transport.
  3. Tono-Pen (Reichert Tonometer):
    • The Tono-Pen is a handheld electronic applanation tonometer.
    • It works by measuring the force required to flatten the cornea, and the reading is displayed electronically.
    • It is often used in clinical settings due to its ease of use and portability.

 

(2) Tonometer with constant pressure and variable area – eg. MALAKOFF’S Tonometer.

 

3-d: Peripheral vision - Perimetry:

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic procedure used to chart the boundaries of a person's visual field. There are two main types of perimetry: kinetic and static perimetry. Kinetic perimetry involves moving a target with a specific luminance from a non-seeing area in the periphery towards the center until the person perceives it. In contrast, static perimetry involves presenting a stationary stimulus and adjusting its intensity until the person either reaches a threshold of detection or can no longer detect it. One type of static perimetry is tangent screen perimetry, which tests the central 30 degrees field at 1 meter and evaluates a person's central vision.

 

Examples of Kinetic Perimetry – Goldmann perimetry and Bjerrum Perimetry

 

Examples of Static Perimetry – Static Automated perimetry – Humphrey Visual Field analyser and Octopus Visual field analyser.

 

4-c: Central vision - Tangent screen test:

 

The tangent screen test is a specific method used to assess central visual field up to 30 degrees from fixation. It involves using a black screen and white or colored targets to determine the sensitivity of central vision, particularly useful in detecting central visual field defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colour vision - Ishihara chart
  • Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer
  • Peripheral vision - Perimetry
  • Central vision - Tangent screen test

questions.text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) functions to stabilize the image on the retina during head movement. What is the ratio of eye velocity to head velocity, known as the VOR gain?  (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) gain is 1, indicating that the eyes move at a compensatory velocity equal to the velocity of the head, but in the opposite direction.

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) allows for eye movements in the opposite direction of head movement to maintain steady gaze and prevent retinal image slip. Nerves involved are 3, 6 & 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct VOR gain is crucial for visual stability. A gain of 1 allows for precise compensation for head movements, ensuring that the visual environment remains stable, which is vital for tasks that involve motion and require steady vision, such as reading while in a moving vehicle or playing sports.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. Fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hard exudate, Diabetes mellitus

 

The given image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with discrete margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetic macular edema.

 

 

COTTON WOOL SPOT vs HARD EXUDATE

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy

 

 

Hypertensive retinopathy

 

 

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) – Fundoscopy reveals massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins. Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft exudate, Hypertension: Soft exudates, also known as cotton wool spots, are whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins.

 

They occur around infarcted areas and result from swelling of nerve fiber layer axons.

 

Associated with hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

 

Option C. Flame-shaped hemorrhages, Hypertension: Flame-shaped hemorrhages are superficial retinal hemorrhages that occur due to disruption of the capillaries in the retinal nerve fiber layer.

 

They are seen in diabetic retinopathy, non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion, traumatic retinopathy, Eale's disease, hypertensive retinopathy, and anemic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterized by massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins.

 

Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

Soft exudates can be seen in CRVO but are not the primary finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hard exudates are characteristic findings in diabetic retinopathy, indicating chronic localized edema and composed of leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages. They present as small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with distinct margins in the retina.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

  • The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis is the inflammation of conjunctiva with formation of very large sized papillae.
  • Etiology - It is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface (contact lens, prosthesis, left out nylon sutures).
  • Symptoms - Itching, stringy discharge and reduced wearing time of contact lens or prosthetic shell.
  • Signs - Papillary hypertrophy (1 mm in diameter) of the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae. Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Treatment:
    1. The offending cause should be removed. After discontinuation of contact lens or artificial eye or removal of nylon sutures, the papillae resolve over a period of one month.
    2. Disodium cromoglycate is known to relieve the symptoms and enhance the rate of resolution.
    3. Steroids are not of much use in this condition.

 

Other Options:

                                        

Option A. In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

 

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

 

 

Option B. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses.

 

The image shows follicles.

 

 

Option D. Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. It is more common during summer. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen.

 

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

 

 

Pseudogerontoxon - Pseudogerontoxon is a lesion that resembles a small segment of arcus senilis or gerontoxon and is seen in many individuals with limbal vernal or atopic keratoconjunctivitis. It is an important clinical finding because pseudogerontoxon is often times the only clinical evidence of previous allergic eye disease.

 

 

Shield Ulcer- Localized oval or pentagonal lesion in upper cornea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is characterized by the presence of large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, often due to a localized allergic response to contact lenses or other foreign bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roenne's nasal step

 

  • Roenne's nasal step is not a feature of the optic disc in glaucoma.
  • Roenne's nasal step is a visual field defect. It is the result of two arcuate scotomas running in different arcs and meeting at the horizontal meridian. This forms a right-angled defect in the nasal side of the visual field.

 

Roenne’s nasal step

 

 

  • Early glaucomatous changes:
    • Increase in cup-disc ratio (C/D ratio) to >0.4
    • Splinter hemorrhages near the optic disc margin
    • Atrophy of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Advanced glaucomatous changes:
    • Marked increase in C/D ratio (0.7 or more)
    • Thinning of the neuroretinal rim
    • Nasal shifting of the retinal vessels or bayonetting
    • Pulsations of retinal arterioles at the disc margin.
    • If the damage progresses, all neural tissue is destroyed and the optic nerve appears white and deeply excavated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bayonetting: This refers to the appearance of blood vessels on the optic disc where the vessels appear to sharply bend or 'bayonet' due to the structural changes in the optic disc from glaucomatous damage, particularly as the neuroretinal rim thins and the cup enlarges.

 

Option C. Increased cup-disc ratio: A hallmark of glaucomatous damage to the optic nerve, where the optic cup enlarges relative to the overall disc, often exceeding a ratio of 0.5, which is considered abnormal and suggestive of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Baring of nasal arteries: This describes the exposure or baring of the nasal retinal arteries as a result of thinning of the nerve fiber layer in glaucoma. It is a less commonly described feature compared to others but can occur as part of the broader pattern of optic nerve head changes in glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Roenne's nasal step, while indicative of the functional impact of glaucoma, does not represent a direct observation of the optic disc but is rather a manifestation of the disease's effect on the visual field.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus since the past 25 years, came for a health checkup. He was found to have uncontrolled blood sugar levels and third cranial nerve palsy. Which is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in such a case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ptosis

 

  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy is caused by hyperglycemia-induced damage to nerve cells and neuronal ischemic change.
  • The arrangement of the fibers in the third cranial nerve is such that the fibers controlling the pupillary reflex are superficial and often spared from diabetic ischemia-induced injury.
  • Pupillary dysfunction is not commonly present in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • The levator palpebrae superiors and most of the oculomotor muscles, except for the lateral rectus and superior oblique, are damaged in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy typically presents with ptosis and diplopia.

 

APPLIED ANATOMY OF PUPILLOMOTOR NERVE FIBRES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proptosis: Protrusion of the eye, not typically associated with diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option B. Pseudoptosis: False appearance of ptosis, not related to actual muscle dysfunction.

 

Option D. Pupillary dysfunction: Although part of the oculomotor nerve's function, it is usually spared in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy due to the peripheral location of the pupillary fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in diabetic patients, due to the selective ischemic damage to the central fibers of the oculomotor nerve, sparing the peripheral pupillary fibers.

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), which of the following findings would be atypical for a classification of 'very severe’? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascularization of disc

 

  • In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), it is important to understand the typical and atypical findings associated with the disease severity:

 

This is considered an atypical finding for NPDR and is generally associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). NVD indicates a more severe and advanced stage where new blood vessels grow on the optic disc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous Bleeding: In NPDR, more common findings are microaneurysms or dot hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhages: Common in NPDR, especially as the severity increases. These hemorrhages are often small and scattered throughout the retina.

 

Option D. Microaneurysm: A hallmark and typically one of the earliest signs of NPDR. These are small, round, red spots seen on fundoscopic examination caused by capillary dilatation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When examining a patient with diabetic retinopathy, finding neovascularization would necessitate reclassification to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires different management strategies including possible laser therapy or anti-VEGF injections to prevent further vision loss.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate brought to the outpatient department is found to have bilateral conjunctivitis. Chest X-ray done showed lung infiltrates. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the infection? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the likely cause of the infection in neonatal conjunctivitis.
  • The infection usually appears 1 week after birth and is transmitted from the mother's cervix or urethra during delivery.
  • Symptoms include edematous conjunctiva, watery discharge that later becomes purulent or bloody.
  • Diagnosis involves taking samples from both the conjunctiva and oropharynx and examining them for intracellular inclusion bodies.
  • Treatment involves administering erythromycin ethylsuccinate 50 mg/kg daily in four divided doses before feeds for 2-3 weeks.
  • If left untreated, associated systemic diseases such as chlamydial otitis and pneumonia may develop later.
  • Both parents must receive appropriate treatment for genital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilus influenzae: This bacterium can cause conjunctivitis but is less likely to present with systemic involvement like pneumonia in the context of neonatal infection.

 

Option C. Streptococcus: While capable of causing neonatal infections, Streptococcus species are more commonly associated with other forms of neonatal morbidity such as sepsis or meningitis, rather than conjunctivitis with pneumonia.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: It is known to cause respiratory infections in older children and adults but is an uncommon cause of neonatal conjunctivitis or pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal conjunctivitis typically presents during the first month of life and the age of the neonate is an important clue to the infection's etiology.

questions.text: Identify the ‘1’ in the picture: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoid Macular Edema

 

  • Cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina centred around the fovea with the formation of tiny cyst-like cavities forming a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography.
  • CME develops due to leakage of fluid following breakdown of inner blood-retinal barrier (i.e., leakage from the retinal capillaries).
  • It is associated with a number of disorders, including postoperative complications following cataract extraction and penetrating keratoplasty, retinal vascular disorders (e.g., diabetic retinopathy and central retinal vein occlusion), intraocular inflammations (e.g., pars planitis, posterior uveitis, Behcet disease), side effects of drugs (e.g., following use of adrenaline eyedrops, especially for aphakic glaucoma, and retinal dystrophies (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa).
  • Clinical manifestations of CME include visual loss, which may be initially minimal to moderate and un-associated with other symptoms, but can progress to permanent decrease in vision if edema persists.
  • CME is best examined with a fundus contact lens on slit-lamp or +90D lens, and typically presents a "Honey-comb appearance" of macula due to multiple cystoid oval spaces on ophthalmoscopy.

 

 

 

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography demonstrates leakage and accumulation of dye in the macular region, which in a well-established case presents a "flower petal appearance".

 

 

Cystoid macular edema (CME) and central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) are two conditions that can affect the macula, the central part of the retina. Here is a table comparing the two conditions:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macular Hole: This would appear as a dark or black spot in the center of the macula due to a full-thickness opening in the retina, which is not observed in this image.

 

Option C. Smoke stack pattern: This pattern would be typical of central serous chorioretinopathy and is characterized by a well-defined, localized leakage point causing fluid to ascend vertically, not seen here.

 

Option D. Age related Macular Degeneration: Typically shows drusen, geographic atrophy, or neovascularization, none of which are evident in this fluorescein angiography image as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) often presents with a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography due to pooling of dye in cystic spaces of the macula and is associated with various underlying conditions affecting the vascular integrity of the retina.

questions.text: A farmer presents with pain and discharge in his left eye. He says that he sustained an injury caused by a leaf a few days back. What is the finding seen in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypopyon  

 

The finding seen in the image is hypopyon.

 

  • Hypopyon is an accumulation of inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, typically seen in the lower part of the chamber as a whitish exudate.
  • In fungal corneal ulcers, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungus can penetrate into the anterior chamber without causing a perforation.
  • Hypopyon associated with anterior uveitis is immobile because of the high fibrin content in the exudate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Hyphema is a hemorrhage in the anterior chamber. It commonly occurs after a blunt ocular injury. The bleeding is from the iris root or ciliary body face. The blood settles inferiorly forming a fluid level.

 

 

Option B: Aqueous flare refers to the haziness of the normally clear fluid in the anterior chamber. It reflects the presence of protein due to the breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier. The presence of flare indicates active inflammation.

 

Option C: Arlt line is the scarring on the conjunctiva in the area of sulcus subtarsalis. It can be a single line, irregularly shaped, or star-shaped. Common causes are trachoma, healed traumatic wounds, or surgical scars.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypopyon is points to severe intraocular inflammation needing prompt treatment to preserve eye function and prevent potential complications. The presence of hypopyon after an injury with organic material highly suggests a fungal etiology, requiring specific antifungal treatment alongside broad-spectrum antibacterial coverage.

questions.text: A patient with glaucoma presents with a bulging cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Staphyloma

 

High intraocular pressure leads to the thinning of the ocular tissue, thereby resulting in a staphyloma.

 

Staphyloma: It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

 

 

Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma.

 

Types of Staphylomas     -

 

 

Note:

 

The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.

 

The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoconus: This condition involves a progressive thinning and coning of the cornea, leading to visual distortion, but it is not typically associated with glaucoma.

 

Option B. Keratomalacia: A severe form of vitamin A deficiency leading to corneal softening. The association between keratomalacia and glaucoma is not typical, as keratomalacia results primarily from nutritional deficiencies.

 

Option D. Granular dystrophy: A type of corneal dystrophy characterized by the accumulation of granular deposits in the cornea. It is a genetically inherited condition, unrelated to the thinning caused by glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphyloma, particularly anterior and ciliary types, can develop due to high intraocular pressure in glaucoma, leading to the protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weakened cornea or sclera.

questions.text: A child presents with sudden loss of vision in one eye, pain on eye movement and there was RAPD. This is due to the lesion of:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Optic nerve

 

The symptoms described are indicative of an issue at the level of the optic nerve, such as optic neuritis, which can cause sudden vision loss, pain on movement of the eye, and RAPD.

 

The optic nerve transmits visual information from the eye to the brain. A lesion in the optic nerve can cause sudden vision loss in one eye, pain with eye movement (often associated with optic neuritis), and an RAPD, where the pupil of the affected eye does not respond as well to light as the unaffected eye due to the reduced sensory input from the retina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Chiasma: The optic chiasma is the part of the brain where the optic nerves partially cross. Lesions at this location typically produce visual field defects in both eyes, such as bitemporal hemianopia, where both outer (temporal) halves of the visual field are lost. It would not typically cause sudden vision loss in one eye, nor would it be associated with pain on eye movement.

 

Option B. Optic Tract: The optic tract carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the lateral geniculate nucleus and other areas. Lesions here can result in homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field cut is observed in both eyes. Like with optic chiasma lesions, optic tract issues do not typically cause sudden unilateral vision loss or pain on eye movement.

 

Option C. Visual Cortex: The visual cortex is located in the back of the brain and is responsible for processing visual information. Damage to the visual cortex can cause a variety of complex visual disturbances, including homonymous hemianopia or cortical blindness, depending on the extent and location of the damage. However, it would not cause unilateral vision loss, pain on eye movement, nor an RAPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of sudden vision loss in one eye, pain on eye movement, and RAPD suggests a lesion in the optic nerve.

questions.text: 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the cause of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retinal detachment

 

Retinal detachment occurs when the sensory retina separates from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. This separation can be due to a retinal break, known as rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, which is the most common type. In patients with high myopia, there is an increased risk of peripheral retinal degeneration, leading to retinal holes that can progress to retinal detachment. The presence of floaters and flashes is a key symptom indicating retinal detachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: This condition typically presents with sudden severe headache and neurological symptoms rather than visual symptoms like floaters.

 

Option C. Vitreous hemorrhage: While this can cause floaters, it is more commonly associated with trauma, diabetic retinopathy, or vascular abnormalities rather than high myopia.

 

Option D. Branched retinal artery occlusion: This condition usually presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in part of the visual field rather than floaters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with high myopia are at increased risk for peripheral retinal degeneration and subsequent retinal detachment, presenting with symptoms like floaters and flashes.

questions.text: First line of treatment for glaucoma in adults is:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PG analogues

 

These are typically the first choice for the long-term management of glaucoma due to their efficacy and favourable patient adherence factors.

 

Prostaglandin analogues are a class of medications used as the first-line treatment for glaucoma. They work by increasing the outflow of the aqueous humor from the eye, which lowers intraocular pressure. These drugs are preferred due to their effectiveness and once-daily dosing, which improves patient compliance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atropine: is a muscarinic antagonist and is not used for the treatment of glaucoma. It dilates the pupil, which can potentially worsen glaucoma, especially angle-closure glaucoma, by blocking the drainage of the aqueous humor from the eye.

 

Option C. Acetazolamide: is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces the production of aqueous humor in the eye, thereby reducing intraocular pressure. It is not typically the first-line treatment due to the potential for systemic side effects and the presence of more effective topical treatments.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: is a cholinergic agonist that contracts the ciliary muscle and opens the trabecular meshwork, allowing for increased outflow of aqueous humor. It is not usually the first choice for the chronic treatment of glaucoma due to its frequent dosing and side effects but can be used in acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for adult glaucoma is Prostaglandin Analogues, which are effective in lowering intraocular pressure with a convenient dosing schedule.

questions.text: Identify the given image:(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central retinal artery occlusion

 

Above image is showing cherry red spot which is seen in central retinal artery occlusion.

 

Central retinal artery occlusion - it occurs due to the blockade of Retinal Artery by thrombus or embolus at lamina cribrosa.

 

Risk factors: old age, atherosclerosis, hypertension, smoking etc.

Symptoms: Sudden painless U/L loss of vision

Signs: Retinal whitening, Cherry red spot

 

DD:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central retinal vein occlusion:

 

Fundoscopic Signs: Flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and optic disc swelling. There is no cherry red spot seen in CRVO.

 

Symptoms: Similar to CRAO with sudden, painless vision loss, but CRVO is associated with hemorrhages and more variable vision loss.

 

Management: Includes addressing complications such as macular edema and neovascularization with treatments like intravitreal injections and laser photocoagulation.

 

Option C. Branched retinal artery occlusion:

 

Fundoscopic Signs: Sectoral retinal whitening corresponding to the area of the blocked artery, but not a generalized cherry red spot.

 

Symptoms: Visual field defects in the area served by the affected artery rather than total vision loss.

 

Management: Similar to CRAO but focused on the affected area, with possible treatments including ocular massage and addressing underlying causes like emboli.

 

Option D. Branched retinal vein occlusion:

 

Fundoscopic Signs: Sectoral retinal hemorrhages, venous tortuosity, and possible cotton wool spots in the affected area.

 

Symptoms: Localized visual field defects rather than total vision loss.

 

Management: Involves treating complications such as macular edema and monitoring for neovascularization, often with intravitreal injections and laser therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "cherry red spot" is a hallmark of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO), which results from the blockage of the retinal artery and leads to retinal ischemia. Immediate management is critical to attempt to restore vision, although the prognosis is generally poor.

questions.text: A patient is experiencing loss of vision on both left sides of the visual fields, but retains the ability to see a small portion in the middle. Based on the history, where is the likely location of the lesion? (FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipital cortex

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Left Macular sparing Homonymous Hemianopia which due to the lesion in Right occipital cortex.

 

VISUAL PATHWAY - Eye (Retina) → Optic Nerve → Optic Chiasm → Optic Tract → Lateral Geniculate Nucleus → Optic Radiation → Visual Cortex

 

  1. Eye (Retina): Light enters the eye and is captured by photoreceptor cells in the retina.
  2. Optic Nerve: The photoreceptor cells in the retina send signals via the optic nerve to the brain.
  3. Optic Chiasm: The optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over at the optic chiasm.
  4. Optic Tract: The fibers continue along the optic tract, which carries visual information from each eye to the brain.
  5. Lateral Geniculate Nucleus: The optic tract fibers terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus.
  6. Optic Radiation: From the lateral geniculate nucleus, the visual information is transmitted via the optic radiation fibers to the visual cortex in the occipital lobe of the brain.
  7. Visual Cortex: The visual cortex processes the visual information to create the perception of vision.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Chiasma: Lesions here typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, characterized by loss of vision in the outer (temporal) halves of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option B. Optic Tract: Lesions here cause homonymous hemianopia, affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes, without macular sparing.

 

Option C. Optic Radiations: Lesions here can cause quadrantanopia, affecting a specific quarter of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the occipital cortex can cause homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, where the patient loses vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes but retains central vision due to the dual blood supply to the macular region.

choices.text: Improves on treatment of thyroid status
Vision loss may be seen in some cases
10% may be euthyroid at presentation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true about the given image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Improves on treatment of thyroid status

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), as seen in the image, is characterized by features like proptosis and upper eyelid retraction. The condition arises from an antigen-antibody interaction, specifically involving antibodies against thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors, which mistakenly cross-react with extraocular muscle proteins. This interaction leads to inflammation, edema, and subsequent enlargement of the muscle belly, sparing the tendons.

 

The disease process is not directly related to the thyroid hormone status of the patient. Thus, managing the thyroid hormone levels does not directly improve TED. Instead, treatments like steroids and radiation therapy are used to control the inflammation and reduce edema. This is why the statement that TED improves with thyroid status treatment is incorrect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vision loss may be seen in some cases: This statement is correct. In TED, the enlarged extraocular muscles within the confined orbital space can compress the optic nerve, leading to compressive optic neuropathy and potential vision loss.

 

Option C. 10% may be euthyroid at presentation: This is true. Even though TED is commonly associated with hyperthyroidism, about 10% of patients can present with normal thyroid hormone levels, or a euthyroid state, because the underlying issue is an immune response rather than hormone levels.

 

Option D. NOSPECS classification is used: Correct. The NOSPECS classification is widely used to grade the severity of thyroid eye disease, ranging from no signs (Class 0) to sight loss (Class 6). This classification helps in assessing and managing the disease progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid eye disease is primarily an immune-mediated condition that does not directly improve with the management of thyroid hormone levels; its treatment focuses on controlling inflammation through immunosuppressive therapies.

questions.text:
Which of the following helps to differentiate a fixed dilated pupil? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Phenylephrine
  2. 1% Pilocarpine
  3. 0.1% Pilocarpine
  4. Cocaine 0.5%
  5. Epinephrine
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3 only

 

Pilocarpine is used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils.

 

2. 1% Pilocarpine

 

 

3. 0.1% Pilocarpine

 

 

Other Options:

 

1. Phenylephrine: This is a sympathomimetic agent that typically dilates the pupil and is not used for differentiating causes of fixed dilation.

 

4. Cocaine 0.5%: Cocaine tests for anisocoria primarily in the context of Horner’s syndrome. It blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, failing to dilate a Horner’s pupil due to sympathetic chain lesion.

 

 

Note - Cocaine and 1% hydroxy amphetamine are used to evaluate anisocoria in smaller pupil.

 

 

5. Epinephrine: Similar to phenylephrine, epinephrine is not used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils but rather to induce dilation for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine at concentrations of 1% and 0.1% is crucial for differentiating causes of fixed dilated pupils, with 1% identifying pharmacological blockade or nerve palsy, and 0.1% detecting hypersensitivity in cases like Adie's pupil.

questions.text: Visual blurring in papilledema is called as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amaurosis fugax

 

Explanation:

 

Amaurosis fugax refers to transient episodes of visual blurring or vision loss.

 

It is often seen in conditions where there is temporary reduction in blood flow to the eye, such as in papilledema. Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head (optic disc) due to increased intracranial pressure. This swelling can cause transient visual disturbances, which are described as amaurosis fugax.

 

In papilledema, the optic nerve head becomes swollen due to stasis of axoplasmic flow, often because of compression or increased pressure on the optic nerve. Despite this swelling, optic nerve function remains normal initially, meaning that central vision, color vision, and pupil reactions are typically preserved. The transient visual blurring episodes (amaurosis fugax) are a key symptom.

                       

Note - Finding in visual field charting (Papilledema)– enlargement of physiological blind spot

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blindness: This refers to complete loss of vision, which is not the case in papilledema where vision disturbances are transient.

 

Option C. Malingering: This term refers to the intentional feigning of illness or symptoms for secondary gain, and is not related to the visual disturbances seen in papilledema.

 

Option D. Corectopia: This is a condition where the pupil is displaced from its normal central position. It is unrelated to the transient visual blurring seen in papilledema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amaurosis fugax refers to transient episodes of visual blurring seen in conditions like papilledema, which is characterized by swelling of the optic nerve head due to increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: What is the photostress test used to differentiate between?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Macula and optic nerve disease

 

  • Photo stress test helps differentiate between diseases involving the macula and optic nerve.
  • This test is particularly useful in early macular diseases like central serous retinopathy.
  • One eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on a near chart.
  • A bright light is shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again.
  • The time taken to recover is noted, and the test is repeated with the other eye.
  • In normal people and patients with optic nerve disease, recovery time is not affected.
  • In patients with macular disease, recovery time is prolonged, usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time.
  • Photoreceptor damage and delayed visual pigment regeneration process contribute to prolonged recovery time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cataract and glaucoma: The photostress test is not designed to differentiate between cataract and glaucoma. Cataract affects the lens, while glaucoma primarily affects the optic nerve and intraocular pressure.

 

Option C. Lens and cornea: The photostress test does not help in differentiating between lens and corneal pathologies. Issues with the lens (e.g., cataracts) and cornea are typically diagnosed with slit-lamp examination and other tests.

 

Option D. Retina and vitreal pathologies: The photostress test is not specifically used to differentiate between retinal and vitreal pathologies. Other diagnostic methods, such as ophthalmoscopy, fundus photography, and optical coherence tomography (OCT), are more appropriate for these conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The photostress test is a simple and effective diagnostic tool used to differentiate between macular diseases and optic nerve diseases, based on the recovery time of vision following bright light exposure.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and eye pain. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. He has been treated both medically and surgically for the condition but showed no improvement. The following procedure incorporates a device to aid drainage. Identify the device.  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ex-Press™ implant

 

The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).
