It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

  • A tiny stainless-steel implant called Ex-PRESS is used to treat glaucoma.
  • It is implanted during a modified trabeculectomy underneath a scleral flap.
  • Hypotony-related complications are less common than with conventional trabeculectomy.
  • By creating a communication between the anterior chamber and the sub-space/sub-conjunctival Tennon's space, glaucoma drainage devices enable aqueous outflow.
  • While formerly only used in high-risk patients or after a failed trabulectomy, these devices are gaining popularity.
  • The commonly used devices are as follows:
    • ﻿﻿Shunts using episcleral explants
    • ﻿﻿Ahmed glaucoma valve- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Molteno implant- Polypropelene plate and silicone plate
    • ﻿﻿Baerveldt implant- Silicone
    • ﻿﻿Mini-shunts
    • ﻿﻿Ex-Press™M Mini-Shunt- Stainless steel
    • ﻿﻿iStent®- Titanium

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ahmed Glaucoma Valve:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Contains a valve mechanism to prevent hypotony.
  • Popular for its ease of implantation and reliable outcomes.
  • Used in cases requiring controlled aqueous humor outflow but differs in design and function from the Ex-Press™ implant

 

Option C. Molteno Implant:

  • Made of polypropylene plate and silicone plate.
  • One of the earliest glaucoma drainage devices, offering various plate sizes.

 

Option D. Baerveldt Implant:

  • Made of silicone.
  • Designed to provide large surface area for filtration.
  • Requires ligation to prevent early postoperative hypotony.
  • Also used for glaucoma management

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant is a minimally invasive device used during modified trabeculectomy to enhance aqueous drainage and reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma. This implant is characterized by its stainless-steel construction and effectiveness in controlling glaucoma with fewer hypotony-related complications.

questions.text: In which of the following is atropine contraindicated? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute congestive glaucoma

 

The use of atropine is not recommended in cases of acute congestive or angle closure glaucoma due to the risk of increasing intraocular pressure.

 

  • Since atropine is a mydriatic, it may lead to the obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris, causing a sudden increase in intraocular pressure.
  • Dim light can also precipitate an attack.
    • Atropine may be indicated as a cycloplegic agent to alleviate pain and prevent synechiae formation in corneal ulcers and acute anterior uveitis.
    • In malignant glaucoma, atropine can be the initial management option.
    • In corneal ulcers, atropine is used as an adjuvant therapy, to reduce pain induced by ciliary muscle spasm via its cycloplegic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute anterior uveitis: Atropine is actually beneficial in cases of acute anterior uveitis. It helps to relieve pain by paralyzing the ciliary muscle and preventing the formation of posterior synechiae (adhesions between the iris and the lens), which can complicate uveitis.

 

Option C. Malignant glaucoma: In malignant glaucoma, atropine might be used as part of the management strategy to try to break the attack by deepening the anterior chamber and pulling the lens-iris diaphragm backward.

 

Option D. Corneal ulcer: Atropine is used in the treatment of corneal ulcers to provide comfort by relieving the painful ciliary spasm and to prevent synechiae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine should be used cautiously, and is contraindicated in acute congestive glaucoma due to its potential to exacerbate the condition by further increasing intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A patient had a cataract surgery 3 years back, now complains of decrease in vision and presented with the following slit lamp image. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior capsular opacification


Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is the most common complication occurring after cataract surgery. It is often referred to as an "after cataract" or "secondary cataract." PCO develops when lens epithelial cells remaining after surgery migrate and proliferate on the posterior capsule, which eventually leads to clouding.

 

The clinical presentation typically involves gradual vision loss without pain, as seen in this case. The slit lamp image provided shows an intraocular lens in place with opacification of the posterior capsule, which confirms the diagnosis of PCO.

 

The standard treatment for PCO is Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy, a simple and effective procedure to restore vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudophakic Bullous Keratopathy: This condition occurs due to endothelial cell loss following cataract surgery, leading to corneal decompensation and formation of painful bullae on the corneal surface. It presents with pain and redness in the eye, which is not observed in this patient.

 

 

Option C. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophy is a genetic disorder that usually presents bilaterally and is unrelated to cataract surgery. It does not cause symptoms similar to those seen in this case and would not present specifically in one eye following cataract surgery.

 

 

Option D. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract: This type of cataract develops in the back of the lens before surgery and is not seen after cataract surgery. Once removed during cataract surgery, posterior subcapsular cataracts do not recur.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Posterior capsular opacification is a common complication after cataract surgery, presenting with gradual vision loss without pain. It is treated with ND laser capsulotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following regimen is commonly used in the treatment of retinoblastoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine, carboplatin and etoposide

 

Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

 

Treatment of retinoblastoma –

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not commonly used for retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used chemotherapy regimen for retinoblastoma includes vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. This combination is effective in reducing tumor size and facilitating further local treatment options.

questions.text: Lagophthalmos is caused by defect in: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 7th cranial nerve

 

Lagophthalmos is the inability to close the eye completely. This condition is caused by a defect in the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve). The facial nerve innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle, which is responsible for closing the eyelid. When this nerve is damaged or dysfunctional, it leads to weakness or paralysis of the orbicularis oculi, resulting in incomplete eyelid closure.

 

 

Note - It's important to distinguish between "lagophthalmos" (inability to close the eye) and "lid lag" (where the eyelid doesn't follow the eyeball's movement properly), as both involve "lag" but refer to different phenomena and are caused by different underlying issues.

 

Lid Lag occurs when the eyelid fails to follow the downward movement of the eyeball when shifting from an upward gaze to a straight or downward gaze. This condition is noticeable in thyroid eye disease and is associated with von Graefe's sign.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve: The oculomotor nerve innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for raising the upper eyelid. A defect in this nerve would cause ptosis (drooping eyelid) rather than lagophthalmos.

 

Option B. 4th cranial nerve: The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is involved in eye movement. It is not directly related to eyelid function.

 

Option C. 6th cranial nerve: The abducens nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for lateral eye movement. It does not control eyelid function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos is caused by a defect in the 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve), which innervates the orbicularis oculi muscle responsible for eyelid closure

questions.text: Which defect is shown below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Homonymous hemianopia

 

The image shows a visual field defect characterized by loss of vision on the right side of the visual field in both eyes, which is termed as homonymous hemianopia. The term "homonymous" indicates that the defect is on the same side of the visual field in both eyes, while "hemianopia" refers to the loss of half of the visual field.

 

This pattern is typically caused by a lesion in the left optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe, which affects the visual field on the opposite side (right side in this case). The defect is contralateral to the side of the lesion, meaning that a left-sided lesion will produce a right-sided visual field loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bitemporal hemianopia: This condition involves the loss of vision in the temporal (outer) fields of both eyes, usually due to a lesion at the optic chiasm, such as from a pituitary tumor. The image does not show this pattern, as only the right visual fields are affected, not the outer fields.

 

Option B. Binasal hemianopia: This defect involves the loss of vision in the nasal (inner) fields of both eyes, often resulting from bilateral optic nerve compression. The visual defect in the image does not match this pattern, as it shows only right-sided field loss.

 

Option C. Altitudinal defect: This type of defect affects the upper or lower half of the visual field in one or both eyes, commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy. The image does not depict an upper or lower field defect; rather, it shows a loss on the right side of both eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homonymous hemianopia is characterized by the loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes and is typically caused by lesions in the contralateral optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female patient presents with complaint of sudden diminishing vision. On examination, relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the right eye and the left eye is normal. Which of the following investigations would you do next? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. MRI brain and orbit
  2. Myelin oligodendrocyte oligoprotein (MOG) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies
  3. Blood sugar
  4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

  • The presented clinical features suggest optic neuritis, which is characterized by sudden, progressive, and profound visual loss along with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
  • The recommended investigations for optic neuritis include MRI brain and orbit, screening for circulating MOG and NMO antibodies, and checking blood sugar levels.
  • Brain MRI is suggested in every patient after the first attack of optic neuritis, as there is a high probability of developing multiple sclerosis.
  • Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a severe type of optic neuritis that can occur bilaterally and is associated with myelitis. The presence of MOG and MO antibodies can diagnose the condition.
  • Reason for checking blood glucose level-
    • If it turns out to be optic neuritis, blood glucose levels should be measured as steroids are mainstay treatment modality
  • Marcus Gunn pupil, which indicates RAPD, is a characteristic sign of optic neuritis. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test, where the eyes' response to light is observed by swinging the flashlight multiple times.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Thyroid profile: This is generally not directly relevant to acute visual changes associated with optic neuritis unless there is a suspicion of thyroid eye disease, which typically presents with other distinctive signs such as exophthalmos, eyelid retraction, and ophthalmoplegia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of sudden visual loss with RAPD, it is crucial to perform a thorough diagnostic evaluation to determine the underlying cause. MRI of the brain and orbits, along with specific antibody tests for MOG and NMO, provide critical information for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of optic neuritis and related conditions. Monitoring blood sugar levels is also essential, especially in the context of potential steroid therapy.

choices.text: Lissamine green dye - visualized under white light
Rose bengal dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter
Fluorescein dye - visualized under red-free filter
Rose bengal dye - visualized under white light

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of dry eye syndrome. On slit lamp examination, the following image shows staining pattern of the conjunctiva. 

 

 

Which of the following combinations is most appropriate for this finding? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lissamine green dye - visualized under white light

 

Explanation:

 

Lissamine green staining viewed under white light is the correct combination in this case. The image shows staining pattern typical of devitalized conjunctival cells, which is better visualized with lissamine green dye under white light illumination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rose bengal dye - visualized under cobalt blue filter: Rose bengal, like lissamine green, stains devitalized cells but is viewed under white light, not cobalt blue filter. Cobalt blue filter is specifically used for fluorescein.

 

Option C. Fluorescein dye - visualized under red-free filter: Fluorescein requires cobalt blue filter for optimal visualization of its fluorescence. Red-free filter is used primarily for retinal examination.

 

Option D. Rose bengal dye - visualized under white light: While rose bengal is indeed viewed under white light, it causes more irritation compared to lissamine green and has largely been replaced by lissamine green for dry eye evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the appropriate combinations of vital dyes and illumination techniques is crucial in ophthalmic examination. Each dye has specific properties and requires specific viewing conditions for optimal visualization of ocular surface pathology.

questions.text: What was ETDRS study related to? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diabetic Macular edema

 

  • Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) was a clinical trial.
  • The study investigated the effect of photocoagulation on diabetic macular edema.
  • The study demonstrated that focal photocoagulation was beneficial in treating diabetic macular edema.
  • The study recommended that eyes with clinically significant diabetic macular edema should be considered for focal photocoagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central retinal artery occlusion: Not the focus of the ETDRS; this condition involves sudden, painless vision loss due to an occlusion in the central retinal artery.

 

Option C. Primary open angle glaucoma: Not related to the ETDRS, which did not address glaucoma treatments or outcomes.

 

Option D. Non-infectious uveitis: Also unrelated to the ETDRS, as the study was specific to diabetic retinopathy and macular edema, not inflammatory eye diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ETDRS study established the beneficial effects of photocoagulation in treating diabetic macular edema, recommending it as an early treatment option to prevent vision loss in patients with clinically significant macular edema.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and an inability to walk. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tay-Sachs disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and fundoscopy image suggest the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase.
  • It presents during infancy with macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, gradual loss of motor skills, and a macular cherry-red spot.
  • Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs and presents with corneal clouding, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, skeletal dysplasia, glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge.
  • Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder that presents with hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, and erosion of long bones caused by the deficiency of B-glucosidase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hunter Disease: Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability. It does not typically present with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy.

 

Option C. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Corneal clouding
    • Coarse facial features
    • Joint stiffness
    • Skeletal dysplasia
    • Glaucoma
    • Retinal degeneration
    • Nasal discharge

 

Option D. Gaucher Disease: Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder caused by the deficiency of β-glucosidase.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Mental retardation
    • Erosion of long bones
    • Cherry-red spot may also be seen, but other clinical features and the typical history of Tay-Sachs make it less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease presents in infancy with progressive neurological decline, macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, and a characteristic macular cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

 

OTHER CAUSES OF CHERRY RED SPOT.

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio.
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is associated with high myopia.

 

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of esotropia and is associated with hypermetropia (farsightedness), not myopia (nearsightedness). The condition often presents in children around 2 to 3 years of age and is characterized by an inward turning of the eyes that is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation).

 

Types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is the most common type of squint: True. Accommodative esotropia is indeed the most common type of esotropia seen in children. This type of squint is related to the effort of focusing (accommodation) and is associated with farsightedness (hypermetropia).

 

Option B. Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio: True. Miotics can be used to manage accommodative esotropia associated with a high AC/A ratio. Miotics reduce the need for accommodation, thereby reducing the associated esotropia.

 

Option D. Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles: True. The refractive type of accommodative esotropia can be fully corrected by using spectacles that correct the hypermetropia. These spectacles reduce the accommodative effort, thereby correcting the esotropia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Accommodative esotropia, the most common type of squint, is associated with high hypermetropia and can often be fully corrected by spectacles. It is not associated with high myopia. Different treatment strategies, including the use of spectacles and bifocals, depend on the specific type and underlying cause of the esotropia.

choices.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complains of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step of management in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irrigation of eye with normal saline

 

 

 

The initial management for any chemical injury to the eye, including chuna (lime) exposure, is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline. This step is crucial to wash out the chemical substance from the eye to minimize further damage. Immediate irrigation helps dilute and remove the chemical agent, reducing the risk of severe injury to the ocular tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics drops in eye: Antibiotic drops are important to prevent infection after the initial management, but they are not the first step. Irrigation must be done first to remove the chemical irritant.

 

Option B. Temporary tarsorrhaphy: Temporary tarsorrhaphy involves partially sewing the eyelids together to protect the eye, but this is not appropriate in the acute phase of a chemical injury. The eye needs to remain open to allow thorough irrigation and drainage of the chemical substance.

 

Option D. Complete Scraping: Complete scraping is a procedure to remove foreign particles embedded in the eye. While this might be necessary if there are chunks of chuna embedded in the conjunctiva, it is not the first step. The initial priority is to irrigate the eye to remove as much of the chemical as possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of chemical injuries to the eye is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline to wash out the chemical substance

questions.text: The child in the picture has large corneas, photophobia, and lacrimation. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital glaucoma

 

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea, along with the image suggests a diagnosis of congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.

 

 

  • Diagnostic features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.
  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy
  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
      • Goniotomy: to remove obstructed tissue in the eye's drainage system.
      • Trabeculotomy: creates a drainage opening in the eye's trabecular meshwork.
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.
      • Trabeculectomy: creates a new drainage channel for aqueous humor.
      • Tube shunt implantation: involves placing a small tube in the eye to drain excess fluid.
      • Ciliary body ablative procedures: destroy the ciliary body to reduce the production of aqueous humor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retinoblastoma: A cancer that would show more than simple enlargement of the corneas, typically presenting with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria).

 

Option C. Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy: Primarily affects the endothelium of the cornea, not associated with the enlargement of the corneas or elevated IOP.

 

Option D. Megalocornea: A non-glaucomatous condition where the corneas are enlarged but without other symptoms like photophobia or increased IOP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital glaucoma is characterized by symptoms like enlarged corneas, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation due to elevated intraocular pressure from developmental anomalies in the anterior chamber angle. Early diagnosis and management are crucial to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: All the following are functions of the superior oblique muscle except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for controlling eye movements. Its primary functions include:

 

  • Abduction: Moving the eyeball away from the midline of the body. The superior oblique helps in turning the eye outward.
  • Depression: Moving the eyeball downward. The superior oblique assists in looking down, especially when the eye is in an adducted position.
  • Intorsion: Rotating the top of the eye towards the nose. This is the action of rotating the eyeball towards the nose, which is an inward rotation.

 

These functions can be remembered using the mnemonic "SOLID," where:

 

  • Superior Oblique LID stands for Lateral (abduction), Intorsion, and Depression.

 

The superior oblique muscle does not perform adduction, which is moving the eyeball towards the midline of the body. This action is typically performed by the recti muscles, specifically the medial rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is responsible for abduction, depression, and intorsion of the eye, but not adduction.

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paralytic squint

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a negative forced duction test.

 

Paralytic Squint:

  • Caused by paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles due to nerve damage or muscle pathology.
  • Secondary deviation (movement of the non-paralyzed eye when the paralyzed eye is fixating) is greater than primary deviation.
  • The forced duction test is negative, indicating no mechanical restriction.
  • Patients may experience diplopia and adopt a compensatory head posture to minimize double vision.

 

Additional Information

 

The squint may be either concomitant or incomitant.

• Concomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes.

• Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes.

 

 

FORCED DUCTION TEST:

 

  • Performed to differentiate between the incomitant squint due to paralysis of extraocular muscle and that due to mechanical restriction of the ocular movements.
  • FDT is positive (resistance encountered during passive rotation) in cases of incomitant squint due to mechanical restriction.
  • FDT is negative in cases of extraocular muscle palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concomitant Squint:

  • The angle of deviation is the same in all directions of gaze.
  • Commonly seen in childhood and associated with hereditary factors, uncorrected refractive errors, or perinatal injury.
  • Diplopia is typically absent because the brain suppresses the image from the deviating eye.

 

Option B.  Restrictive Squint:

  • Caused by mechanical restriction of the extraocular muscles due to conditions like thyroid eye disease, trauma, or fibrosis.
  • The forced duction test is positive, indicating resistance during passive eye movement due to mechanical restriction.
  • Diplopia is often present, and the degree of deviation varies depending on the direction of gaze.

 

Option D.  Pseudosquint:

  • An apparent squint where there is no actual misalignment of the eyes.
  • Commonly due to facial anatomical features such as epicanthal folds or a wide nasal bridge.
  • No actual deviation is present, and there are no associated symptoms like diplopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paralytic squint is characterized by secondary deviation greater than primary deviation and a negative forced duction test, indicating the absence of mechanical restriction.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left occipital lobe

 

  • The visual field defect is right homonymous hemianopia with macular-sparing.
  • It is caused by lesions of the left occipital lobe, which is contralateral/crossing of fibers.
  • Head injury is a common cause of such lesions.
  • These lesions may be associated with visual hallucinations, denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and the Riddoch phenomenon.
  • These lesions are commonly due to occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The part of the occipital lobe representing the peripheral field vision is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
  • The lesions generally spare the central vision/macular vision since the area at the tip of the calcarine cortex, representing the central macular vision, is supplied by a branch of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Occipital Lobe: This would cause a left-sided homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option C. Left Geniculate Body: Lesions here typically produce similar visual field defects as occipital lobe lesions but may have different associated clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, which is not demonstrated in the visual field tests provided.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the left occipital lobe is the most likely cause of the right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing shown in the visual field tests. This understanding is critical for accurately diagnosing the underlying condition, potentially a vascular event, and directing appropriate management and intervention strategies.

questions.text: A 59-year-old patient who underwent cataract surgery, presented with gradual diminution of vision in the operated eye, suggesting secondary cataract. Which laser is used for the management of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nd:YAG

 

  • Posterior capsular opacification is also known as “after cataract” or “secondary cataract”.
  • It is a late complication of cataract surgery.
  • There are three morphological types: Elschnig pearls (most common), Sommering ring, and diffuse membranous.
  • Symptoms include a gradual, painless decrease in vision.
  • Treatment involves the use of laser Nd:YAG (1064 nm wavelength). Tough and nonpliable membrane have first to be cut into smaller pieces by Ziegler knife or vitreous scissor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femto second laser: Used in LASIK, cataract surgery, corneal transplant, and keratoconus treatment, but not for treating secondary cataract.

 

Option C. EXCIMER: Used for photorefractive keratectomy (PRK), LASIK, phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK), and corneal cross-linking, but not for secondary cataract.

 

Option D. Argon laser: Used in retinal photocoagulation, trabeculoplasty, and iridotomy, but not for secondary cataract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Various lasers and their uses in ophthalmological procedures: -

questions.text: Where is Scarpa's Staphyloma typically observed? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myopia

 

Explanation:

 

Scarpa's Staphyloma, also known as Posterior Staphyloma, is most commonly associated with pathologic myopia. It is characterized by an outpouching or ectasia of the sclera at the posterior pole of the eye, which is typically lined by the choroid and retina. This condition reflects a localized area of weakness where the sclera has become thinned and is pushed outward by intraocular pressure, most often in the context of severe myopia .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal Detachment: While retinal detachment can occur in patients with severe myopia due to the stretching and thinning of the retina, it is not directly associated with the formation of a staphyloma, which is a scleral deformation.

 

Option C. Glaucoma: Glaucoma primarily affects the optic nerve and intraocular pressure regulation, and does not cause staphylomas, which are structural deformations of the sclera.

 

Option D. Iridocyclitis: This condition involves inflammation of the iris and ciliary body and does not lead to structural changes like the formation of a staphyloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scarpa’s Staphyloma is a hallmark of pathologic myopia and involves the outward bulging of the sclera at the posterior pole of the eye.
